title: State v. Williams - Competency Evaluation (Intellectual Disability)
question: Competency to stand trial
summary: Defendant with Mild Intellectual Disability and PTSD assessed for competency to stand trial. Full-scale IQ of 65 on WAIS-IV, with significant deficits in abstract reasoning and verbal comprehension. PTSD symptoms from childhood trauma impair concentration and memory. Cannot adequately understand court proceedings or assist counsel with defense. Poor prognosis for competency restoration due to cognitive limitations being permanent. Raises ethical questions regarding indefinite incompetency.

documents.description: Comprehensive competency evaluation with cognitive testing and trauma assessment
60-day follow-up assessment showing lack of progress in competency restoration

key_findings: Mild Intellectual Disability - WAIS-IV Full Scale IQ: 65 (1st percentile)
Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder related to childhood physical and sexual abuse
Special education placement throughout school years; never progressed beyond 6th grade level
Cannot understand abstract legal concepts (burden of proof, plea bargaining, witness examination)
PTSD symptoms (intrusive thoughts, hyperarousal, avoidance) further impair concentration and memory
NOT competent to stand trial - lacks rational and factual understanding of proceedings
Poor prognosis for restoration - cognitive deficits are permanent, not amenable to brief educational intervention
Raises Jackson v. Indiana concerns regarding indefinite commitment for unrestorable incompetency
